sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Indian Removal. The Trail of Tears (1830-1838). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Sarah, age 14, Cherokee girl, 1838.

I'm Sarah, fourteen years old, Cherokee. My people have lived in these Georgia mountains for generations—longer than anyone can remember. We're not the "savages" white people imagine. We have farms, schools, a written language created by Sequoyah, our own newspaper.
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Sarah, fourteen years old, Cherokee.

sections.narration: In 1830, Congress passed the Indian Removal Act. President Jackson claims it's voluntary—tribes can choose to move west of the Mississippi to "Indian Territory" in exchange for their eastern lands. But everyone knows the truth: refuse, and you'll be forced out anyway. Jackson argues removal benefits us.
visuals: Chapter title: The Indian Removal Act
sections.key_takeaway: In 1830, Congress passed the Indian Removal Act.

sections.narration: Spring 1838. Soldiers arrive with guns and bayonets. General Winfield Scott commands 7,000 troops to round up Cherokee and force us west. They give us no time to gather belongings, to harvest crops, to bury our dead properly.

sections.section: Chapter 4: The Trail Where We Cried
sections.narration: October 1838. We begin the thousand-mile march to Oklahoma. Over 16,000 Cherokee forced west in groups. It's cold already, and we're not prepared.
visuals: Chapter title: The Trail Where We Cried

sections.narration: We reached Indian Territory in March 1839. Of 16,000 who started, only about 12,000 arrived. Over 4,000 dead—a quarter of our people. And we're not the only ones—Creek, Seminole, Chickasaw, Choctaw all suffered similar removals.
sections.key_takeaway: We reached Indian Territory in March 1839.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored Indian Removal through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Indian Removal Act, Trail of Tears, Cherokee Nation, Sequoyah.
